/var/cache/apt/archives
cool, what about part 2...I see, excellent! I'll try it!

I am planning to (got that) reinstall this system. It is currently set up to dual boot, but the kernel is a bit bloated, so I want to streamline things a bit.
I have no done an install from CD, will I get an oppertunity to customize the kernel on setup, or do I have to make install?
that's ok, I'll look around for a description of the CD install option. Thanks! (aptoncd, that is!)
sorry, was afk. Ubuntu doesn't have an option to customize the kernel during installation.
really...I wanted to remove support for devices I dont have on my system. It seems that the kernel loads a lot of stuff on boot that I don't / need.
really. I believe the thinking is that custom kernel compiling is somewhat outside of Ubuntu's scope.
considering that most of the really unnecessary stuff is compiled as modules, rather than into the kernel, there really isn't much of a performance benefit from custom compiling one.
yes
I want to be able to clone voicemail system HDDs, I figure I can add a second drive, boot into live CD than go from there; does that sound about right?
What's the advantage of that, bein' curious.

There are plenty of applications for it. You can mount .iso files like they were actual devices (mount -o loop /path/to/file), or do something like Wubi where you have an entire Ubuntu partition inside a file on an NTFS partition...
It would be cool to be able to mount an iso file!
curious, what's wrong with network-manager?
no, that's the alternate version. the server version has "server" where yours has "alternate"...
I need server, but also software raid support. Read about it and asked here - alternate was suggested.

the alternate CD and server CD use the same installer (and both support RAID). server uses a different kernel with various configuration changes optimized for servers, alternate uses the normal desktop kernel.
dohhh, oh well - now I have both!
